Phobias, PTSD, and depression are real illnesses.  They are not weaknesses of character or something you can control or even manage without great difficulty.  Are you getting any treatment for your depression?   Do you have a support system--friends or family members you trust?  Are you getting therapy from a mental health professional and is it helping you move forward?  Ask for a recommendation for a doctor who is known to be particularly kind and compassionate.  Then with the assistance of someone you trust, try to take that first step and call for an appointment.  The first thing the doctor needs to hear from you is an expression of your fears so he/she can proceed is a slow and gentle manner with you.   Depression, PTSD, and phobias are treatable but will require time and effort before you will see improvement.  That first step is yours, but do enlist the support of a friend.

question: I don't know if I'm in the right place to ask this question but please help if you can...I'm a 40 yo female in good health (I think, haven't had a REAL physical in almost 5 years...have a terrible needle phobia) I suffer from depression, and ptsd (which is why I'm not sure I'm in the right place to ask for advice).  I've been having tightness in my chest for long periods of time (not just 30 mins like a panic attack), sometimes hours..also feels like a fluttering in my chest.  Now for the past 2 days I've been having pain (mild to moderate) in the flank area of my back, just above my waist.  I'm not a hypochondriac, just have the terrible fear of needles/doctors/hospitals.  I am trying to tell myself these symptoms are just connected to my depression/ptsd, but I'm also worried it may be something more serious.  Heart disease does not run in my family, diabetes does. I do not smoke, am on Weight Watchers diet I'm 5'5 and weigh 159.  Please advise if possible.
